title: London house price falls: where to snap up a bargain in pricey neighbourhoods
text:
It’s hard to avoid the fact that in much of London, property price growth has ground to a halt, and that prices may even be ­falling.

The (last) peak of the London market is generally accepted as being the end of 2015. Since then, the market has been pummelled by the double whammy of stamp duty increases – on homes above £937,500 (and also an ­extra 3 per cent on second homes) – and Brexit uncertainty.

London is a patchwork of micro-markets, but have any of our old ­favourite areas got any cheaper? ­Discounting the most expensive homes, and markets driven by spec­ulative investors, what about the areas popular with families or first-time ­buyers for their convenient transport links or local lifestyle?...
description: It’s hard to avoid the fact that in much of London, property price growth has ground to a halt, and that prices may even be ­falling.
